term: Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Ratio Test
template_fields: [•]x, applicable to [•]
analysis_guidelines: Consider ratio governor on builder usage for restricted payments as conservative flex.
background: Adding a ratio governor to use the builder for RPs (e.g., a total leverage cap) ties leakage to sustained performance. The sources show this as an effective flex lever to align RP usage with investor expectations without rewriting the builder components.

template_fields: [Note any issues with respect to the Available Amount build]
analysis_guidelines: Align Cumulative Credit parameters to precedent; clarify any and all elements of Available Amount
background: Other elements include equity proceeds and returns on investments. Sources warn that uncapped returns on investments and inclusion of asset sale proceeds unswept due to stepdowns can inflate capacity and convert investment capacity into RP capacity; careful drafting avoids double counting and limits inclusion to amounts originally funded from the builder basket.

template_fields: **Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates**
background: The affiliate transactions covenant requires arm’s-length terms for dealings with affiliates and often carves out the sponsor management agreement. Sources recognize de minimis thresholds, board approval/fairness opinion constructs for larger deals, and caution against broad exclusions that would render the covenant duplicative of other covenants.

term: Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold
analysis_guidelines: Include de minimis thresholds; align with precedent because notes are high-level.
background: A de minimis threshold for affiliate transactions filters out small ordinary-course items from review. Sources suggest pairing with arm’s-length standards and fairness opinions for large transactions to protect creditors from value leakage to affiliates.

term: Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees
template_fields: * Permitted [to the extent permitted by the sponsor management agreement] and [not] subject to any default block * Does not state amount of fee / references the management agreement * [Permits other [customary] fees approved by the Board] Permits Sponsor and its affiliates to acquire debt of the Borrower and its restricted subs
analysis_guidelines: Permit fees per management agreement; consider allowing other customary board-approved fees; allow sponsor debt purchases subject to general assignment and affiliated lender provisions.
background: Sponsor management fee payments are typically permitted per the closing date agreement and amendments not materially adverse to lenders, or subject to a dollar cap. The sources stress that other affiliate transfers should satisfy arm’s-length standards and remain subject to RP limits.

term: Other Term Sheet Issues – LCT, EoDs, Voting, Assignments, Pricing
template_fields: *Other Term Sheet Issues – LCT, EoDs, Voting, Assignments, Pricing**
background: “Limited Condition Transactions” (LCT) allow ratio and covenant testing at signing of a definitive agreement rather than at closing for acquisitions, with subsequent tests done pro forma for the transaction. Events of Default, sacred rights, and assignment provisions should incorporate contemporary protections against LMEs (Serta/NYDJ), vote-rigging (Wesco/Incora), and net-short activism, while pricing and MFN constructs should reflect current SOFR-based yield practice.

template_fields: * Applies not only to permitted acquisitions the consummation of which financing is not a condition but also other investments, RPs, RDPs, dispositions and similar transactions * Subsequent tests are pro forma [and also actual basis for RPs and RDPs] * [Includes outside date of [x] days] [RCF draws subject to LCT provisions]
analysis_guidelines: Clarify if LCT is applicable beyond acquisitions to investments, RPs, RDPs, dispositions; subsequent tests on pro forma basis; consider outside date and RCF draw applicability consistent with notes.
background: Limited Condition Transaction “LCT” provisions fix testing metrics at the LCT election point (e.g., acquisition signing) for baskets and ratios, insulating from interim fluctuations. The sources support extending LCT to related dispositions, RPs, and RDPs tied to the acquisition, with an outside date to avoid indefinite reliance and clarity on whether revolver draws can be LCT-tested.

template_fields: * [•] grace period for interest; [•] for other amounts * 30 day grace period for misrepresentations capable of being cured * $[•] cross-default threshold * [Includes ‘cured default’ language] * [[•] statute of limitations] * [Includes ‘net short’ provisions]
analysis_guidelines: Include 5-day interest grace; 30-day misrepresentation cure; cross-default/cross-acceleration to material debt; ensure financial covenant default does not trigger term loan EoD unless revolver accelerates.
background: Standard EoDs include payment defaults with short grace for interest, covenant breaches with cure periods where appropriate, cross-default or cross-acceleration to material debt, and insolvency. The sources also discuss “net-short” voting disenfranchisement to deter activism and limit maintenance-covenant breaches to revolver remedies.

template_fields: * [Describe terms] * [Can be sold to other portcos / continuation funds] * [Uncapped management/closing date investors] * [Includes Change of Control portability on the following terms: [•]]
analysis_guidelines: Avoid portability; cover holdings-level defaults; require offers to prepay/purchase at change-of-control levels consistent with bridge/exchange notes comparables.
background: Change of control typically triggers a mandatory prepayment offer (loans) or put (notes) and an EoD under bank facilities if not taken up. The materials discourage portability in sponsor deals and recommend alignment of CoC mechanics across bank and bridge/exchange note components.

template_fields: * [Includes] / [Does not include] Serta protection [describe formulation] * [Incora protection [included] / [not included]] * [Release of all/substantially all guarantees/collateral is a majority vote] * [Include small group voting provisions – i.e. 2 or more unaffiliated lenders?] * [Is waterfall, pro rata payments and sharing an affected lender vote? Are there any other holes in the voting structure?] * [Waiving payment defaults is a Req Lender vote, creating a perpetual standstill]
analysis_guidelines: List all sacred right protections (i.e. changes requiring all/all affected lender consent); Clarify if Serta blocker included and the specific elements; clarify if Serta blocker applies across both lien and payment subordination; NYDJ: clarify if affected-lender consent required for waterfall/pro rata amendments; Clarify if Incora included (sacred-rights protections incremental issuance to manipulate votes)
background: The sources define “Serta” blockers requiring affected lender consent for lien/payment subordination and “NYDJ” protections for waterfall and pro rata sharing. They also note post-LME practices adding sacred-rights protections against using extensions or incremental issuance to manipulate votes (Wesco/Incora) and limiting the influence of small, concentrated groups.

template_fields: * [Describe deemed consent, sponsor/borrower consent] * [Identify unusual limits – can loans be pledged for leveraged facilities?] * DQ List – [describe (i) whether it can be updated (and if just competitors), (ii) if it is available to other lenders, (iii) when the updates apply and (iv) if it applies after a payment/bankruptcy EoD]
analysis_guidelines: Clarify deemed borrower consent, sponsor/borrower consent parameters, DQ list update mechanics post-signing and pre-closing as well as post-closing, and applicability post-default.
background: Assignment provisions balance borrower consent rights and lender liquidity. Sources recommend deemed consent after a set period, clarity on sponsor consent where applicable, visibility of the DQ list to assignees, and fallaway of consent rights upon specified defaults, while preserving agent KYC and operational controls.

template_fields: * [Permitted on a [non-]pro rata basis]
analysis_guidelines: If permitted, align with Serta protections and sharing provisions; confirm whether open-market purchases are affected-lender votes.
background: Borrower/affiliate loan purchases should be for cash, not funded with revolver proceeds, and—if held by the borrower or its subs—typically be canceled. The sources stress ensuring that buyback mechanics cannot be used to effect non-pro rata LME exchanges and that voting is handled per affiliated lender rules.

template_fields: * [•]% cap * No cap on number of affiliated lenders * No express voting limits in bankruptcy Not limited to term loans (i.e. can buy back revolver)
analysis_guidelines: Cap affiliated debt funds at 49.9% for Required Lenders; avoid general voting restrictions but flag bankruptcy voting considerations; clarify revolver buyback permissions.
background: Affiliated Lenders are split between Debt Fund Affiliates and other affiliates. Sources endorse a 49.9% cap on Debt Fund Affiliates counting toward Required Lenders, deem-voting for non-debt-fund affiliates, and caps (e.g., 25–30%) on aggregate non-debt-fund affiliate holdings to prevent blocking positions in bankruptcy, with revolver assignments typically prohibited.

template_fields: * Not required to be cancelled * No prohibition on use of revolver * Not subject to no EoD * Assignments to unrestricted subsidiaries not required to be cancelled
analysis_guidelines: If buybacks are not required to be cancelled, confirm pro rata and sharing; consider prohibiting revolver usage and applying default stoppers as conservative flex.
background: Borrower/subsidiary buybacks are usually permitted for cash and canceled upon purchase to avoid voting manipulation. The sources caution against allowing buybacks funded with revolving loans and recommend default stoppers and pro rata Dutch auction mechanics where buybacks are permitted.

term: Assignments – voting limit on Debt Fund Affiliates
analysis_guidelines: Adopt 49.9% cap for required lender determinations consistent with notes’ affiliated debt fund treatment.
background: Debt Fund Affiliates may vote but should not constitute a majority of Required Lenders alone. The sources reflect a common 49.9% cap, ensuring non-affiliated lenders are needed for majority actions, while still permitting debt funds to be significant constituents.

template_fields: [None] [[ ] has the right to co-invest $[ ] on same terms/price as Sponsor and w/ customary minority protections
analysis_guidelines: If included, define minority protections and pricing parity; the notes are silent—confirm business grid.
background: Equity co-invest rights for lenders or sponsors should specify right of first refusal mechanics, pricing parity, and governance/minority protections. The sources do not prescribe terms; align with sponsor’s broader equity program and avoid conflicts with financing conditions.

template_fields: * [Hardwired pricing through delivery of financials for [ ] quarter post-closing] * [•]% of interest rate margin starting [•] and increasing to [•]% at [•]] * [additional step down of [ ] bps upon consummation of an IPO] [PIK Interest]
analysis_guidelines: Hardwire initial pricing post-closing; consider margin step-downs tied to leverage and IPO; PIK only if structured as agreed; ensure MFN and Total Cap alignment where bridge features exist.
background: Pricing includes SOFR margins, OID/upfront fees, and potential step-downs upon leverage improvement or an IPO. For bridges, total yield caps and step-ups are standard; sources advise ensuring MFN calculations use all-in yield and allowing flex to convert margin increases into OID if needed for syndication.

analysis_guidelines: Confirm benchmark floors consistent with fee letter and market flex; notes are silent on specific levels.
background: Benchmark floors protect lender yield when reference rates fall. Although the sources don’t fix levels, ensure floor levels align with fee letter flex (and MFN “all-in yield” math) and are consistent across original and incremental tranches for comparability.

template_fields: [[ ] bps with [ ] stepdown(s) at [ ]x [FLNLR]]
analysis_guidelines: Align fee to leverage tests and stepdowns; confirm sacred-rights treatment for changes to super-senior RCF caps.
background: Revolver commitment fees compensate for undrawn availability; step-downs at lower leverage are common. The sources suggest treating super-senior revolver cap increases as sacred rights and aligning fee adjustments across incremental revolver capacity to keep syndicate expectations stable.

analysis_guidelines: Apply 50% of term margin stepping to full margin over time; accrues from closing to takedown or expiry, consistent with notes.
background: DDTL ticking fees typically accrue at 50% of the applicable SOFR margin, stepping up over time or to full margin after a set period, per the sources. This compensates commitment providers for time risk and encourages timely takedowns.

analysis_guidelines: Confirm fee consistent with LC usage and sublimits; notes do not fix percentages—use precedent calibration.
background: LC fronting fees compensate the issuing bank for LC exposure; calibrate to precedent for transaction size and LC usage profile. Ensure consistency with LC participation fees payable to revolver lenders and with any multi-currency LC program.

Second lien facilities mirror first lien structures with set-backs. Sources address cushions on baskets, cross-default/acceleration formulations, and ensuring covenant setbacks so first lien lenders control collateral enforcement and sweeps until their discharge, including mandatory prepayments sequencing.

template_fields: [•]%, applicable to $ baskets [and ratios]
analysis_guidelines: Apply 20–30% cushions on fixed-dollar and grower baskets; 0.25x ratio cushions where proposed; consider flex to shrink or remove ratio cushion per notes.
background: Second lien baskets and ratios should be tighter than first lien’s to reflect junior position. The materials cite common practice of smaller fixed/grower baskets and modest ratio cushions (e.g., 0.25x tighter), which lenders may further tighten through flex to avoid crowding first lien headroom.

template_fields: [Not] included
analysis_guidelines: If included, ensure it prevents incurrence of structurally senior debt ahead of second lien; the notes do not detail—confirm with intercreditor norms.
background: Anti-layering provisions restrict incurring additional debt that is senior to the second lien but junior to first lien, preserving the intended two-tier capital structure. The sources encourage aligning with intercreditor agreements to avoid unintended priority shifts.

template_fields: Cross-acceleration [and cross-payment default] to [other indebtedness] / [first lien] [at maturity]
analysis_guidelines: Prefer cross-acceleration and cross-payment default at maturity; avoid cross-default to first lien financial covenant breaches, per notes.
background: Cross-default mechanics in second lien should reference payment defaults and acceleration under first lien debt but avoid triggering on first lien maintenance covenant breaches. This prevents junior creditors from accelerating based on super-senior maintenance test outcomes.

template_fields: Only required after first lien terminated
analysis_guidelines: Second lien mandatory prepayments should be required only after first lien is terminated, per notes’ covenant set-back philosophy.
background: Mandatory prepayment waterfalls should prioritize first lien repayment; second lien sweeps should occur only after first lien discharge or in amounts clearly subordinated by intercreditor terms. The materials emphasize this “set-back” consistency across covenants and sweep sections.

template_fields: **Conditions Annex**
background: The Conditions Annex implements Sungard limited conditionality: funding is conditioned only on Specified Representations, Specified Acquisition Agreement Representations, delivery of essential collateral/perfection steps (UCCs and stock certificates as available), MAC linked to the M&A definition as of signing, and delivery of specified financial statements/marketing information for bridges.

template_fields: Majority, rather than all lenders
analysis_guidelines: Permit majority waivers rather than unanimity to avoid funding risk; confirm scope consistent with LCT.
background: Funding conditions should be waivable by the commitment parties holding a majority of commitments, not unanimity, to avoid execution risk. The sources tie this to LCT constructs and the need to complete underwritten acquisitions without minority vetoes.

template_fields: * [Only “making” of specified reps/specified acquisition agreement reps] * MAC to conform to acquisition agreement Specified Reps limited to Holdings and AcquisitionCo
analysis_guidelines: Limit to “making” of Specified and Specified Acquisition Agreement Reps; align MAC definitions to acquisition agreement; restrict reps to Holdings/Borrower as appropriate.
background: Under Sungard, only Specified Reps (existence, power, enforceability, solvency, margin regs, Investment Company Act, sanctions/anti-corruption use-of-proceeds, and creation/perfection) and Specified Acquisition Agreement Reps must be accurate for funding. Other reps are made but not closing conditions.

template_fields: * Any change in MAE definition [is] / [is not] materially adverse * Arrangers deemed to consent to changes within [•] days * [Purchase price reductions [less than [•]] deemed not to be materially adverse] [Purchase price reductions greater than [•] permitted so long as first applied to reduce Equity Contribution to min. % and thereafter the term facilities are ratably reduced] [Consider minimum size on any second lien] * [Purchase price increases permitted if funded with permitted debt/revolver/equity]
analysis_guidelines: Treat MAE definition changes as material and adverse; provide deemed consents within a short window where not materially adverse; handle purchase price adjustments via equity and ratable term facility reductions as noted.
background: Commitment conditions tie to the acquisition agreement as executed on signing. The sources require consent for any materially adverse amendments, deem changes to the MAE definition per se adverse, and specify that purchase price reductions reduce term loan size dollar-for-dollar (subject to a floor), aligning debt with value.

template_fields: * [Specify refinanced debt and whether any debt survives]
analysis_guidelines: Specify refinanced debt and whether any debt survives; coordinate with collateral termination and LC backstops.
background: The Conditions Annex should list debt to be repaid or addressed at closing and ensure liens are released, commitments terminated, and any residual contingent obligations (e.g., LCs) are backstopped or cash collateralized to the arrangers’ satisfaction.

template_fields: * Runs from date of signing Only applies if acquiror can terminate the acquisition as a result
analysis_guidelines: MAC runs from acquisition agreement signing and applies only if acquiror can terminate; notes emphasize the importance of MAC even if proof burdens are high.
background: The MAC condition looks to the acquisition agreement’s MAE/MAC definition as of signing and runs from signing to closing, consistent with the buyer’s closing condition. Sources stress lenders’ reliance on this even though MAE findings are rare under Delaware law.

template_fields: * [Does not include officer’s certificate] * Solvency certificate only covers Borrower and restricted subs * [Note any certain funds limitations on the collateral –i.e. is only the pledge of borrower/loan party equity required?]
analysis_guidelines: Include legal opinions, secretary/incumbency certificates, solvency certificate covering the consolidated group, borrowing base certificate for ABL, and notice of borrowing; confine stock delivery to borrower equity at closing per notes.
background: Closing deliverables comprise customary legal opinions, organizational certificates, a CFO solvency certificate covering the consolidated group post-Transactions, notices of borrowing, and, for ABLs, borrowing base certificates. Under Sungard, only UCCs and readily deliverable stock certificates are conditions; other perfection steps are post-closing.

template_fields: * [Summarize required financials] * [Confirm client has received] * [Confirm if subsequent financials between signing/closing are required if not provided for]
analysis_guidelines: Require audited for two most recent fiscal years (≥90 days before closing) and unaudited quarters (≥45 days before closing; not Q4), per notes; bridge offerings need offering document-ready packages.
background: For bank facilities, audited financials for the two most recent years and interim quarterlies support closing diligence; for bridges, a preliminary offering memorandum suitable for a high-yield roadshow plus auditor “comfort” is required, with marketing periods keyed to receipt of “Required Information.”

template_fields: * [Confirm any required ‘soft notice’ of closing date to ensure funding availability] * Does not include [express condition that specified reps and acquisition agreement reps are true] [express condition that minimum equity contribution is made] * Inside date is not specified ([•] in Acquisition Agreement) * No diligence condition * No IC approval condition * [No condition that remaining commitments must be received from other lenders] * Is a VCOC letter required? * Will there be an equity co-invest or warrants? [is this a CP?]
analysis_guidelines: Include soft notice of closing date; avoid diligence or IC approval conditions at closing once “Sungard” is in place; consider VCOC letters, co-invests, or warrants only if business grid requires.
background: “Soft” closing date notices help operational readiness but are not conditions. The sources caution against including credit committee approvals or extra diligence as conditions inconsistent with Sungard; ancillary sponsor items (e.g., VCOC letters) should be outside closing conditions or tied to business terms.

template_fields: *Fee Letter**
background: The fee letter houses economics and market flex. The sources recommend aligning flex items to the indicative terms and precedent, defining OID/fees that may be used for MFN “all-in yield,” and including alternate transaction fees/ROFR mechanics and drag-along flex for second lien if applicable.

template_fields: * [First Lien] Term Loan: [•]% of commitments [at signing] / [at closing] * Revolver: [•]% of commitments [at signing] / [at closing] * [DDTL: [•]] [Note this typically matches term loan, split 50% at close/draw or less commonly at termination] [Second Lien Term Loan: [•]% of commitments [at signing] / [at closing]
analysis_guidelines: Pay on signing or closing per facility; for DDTLs, clients prefer full fee at closing akin to revolver commitments; borrowers may push for 50%/50% split—flag as a key economics issue.
background: Underwriting and arrangement fees are typically payable at closing for funded term loans; for DDTLs, the sources reflect lender preference to charge full fees at closing (commitment in place), while borrowers argue for partial payment on closing and balance on takedown. This is a core negotiation point highlighted in the materials.

template_fields: * First Lien [(including revolver)]: $[•] * [Second Lien: $[•]]
analysis_guidelines: Confirm structuring fee sizing across first lien (including revolver) and second lien per precedent and market; notes provide no fixed figures.
background: Structuring fees compensate for complexity in multi-tranche or bespoke features. Align with comparable recent deals in sector and size and ensure fees are included in “all-in yield” for MFN purposes where relevant.

template_fields: * [•]% of interest rate margin starting [•] and increasing to [•]% at [•]]
analysis_guidelines: Apply a percentage of interest margin starting after a defined period and increasing with time; coordinate with market flex provisions.
background: Ticking fees accrue when closing is delayed past a set date, typically at a percentage of the term margin and stepping up with time. The sources recommend aligning start dates, step-ups, and conversion to OID under flex to manage syndication yield needs.

analysis_guidelines: Set at 50% of SOFR margin stepping to full margin; accrues from closing until takedown or expiry, per notes.
background: For DDTLs, ticking fees typically start at 50% of the SOFR margin and step to full margin after a period, compensating for undrawn committed capital. This is consistent with the source guidance on DDTL economics.

analysis_guidelines: Confirm agency fee consistent with role scope; notes are silent—use precedent.
background: Administrative and collateral agency fees depend on transaction complexity and collateral scope. Use recent precedent with similar borrower footprints and lien packages; set second lien agent fees with an appropriate set-back given smaller workload.

template_fields: * 12 months; 50% of upfront fees [calculated as the “lesser of” committed and alternate facility fees] * ROFR, without requirement for same roles/economics, with customary sponsor exceptions * ROFR applies to the acquisition and alternate acquisition
analysis_guidelines: Twelve months; 50% of upfront fees; include ROFR without same roles/economics requirement; adopt carveouts where lenders exercise “outs” or withhold approvals, consistent with notes.
background: Alternate transaction fees compensate commitment parties if the borrower pivots to different financing. The sources show 12-month tails at 50% of upfront fee levels with carveouts if commitment parties invoked outs or refused reasonable amendments; ROFRs are typically included without guarantees of identical roles/economics.

template_fields: * Can commit up to [•]% of [•] within [•] days * [Entitled to [•]% share of fees on committed amount] / [Initial lenders not entitled to fees on sponsor allocation]
analysis_guidelines: Define sponsor commit rights and fee shares on sponsor allocations; notes do not specify—confirm in grid and fee letter.
background: Where sponsors or affiliates take down debt allocations, allocate proportionate fees or carve out fee reductions for affiliate allocations as agreed. The sources suggest clarifying this in the grid and fee letter to avoid disputes during allocation.
